evidence.phenotypeFreeText: chronic respiratory complaints, the axoneme ultrastructure of nasal cilia revealed the absence of DA and DRC , and the determination of the ciliary beat axis and ciliary deviation showed a high SD , which corroborates the diagnosis of PCD this patient.

dc:source.dc:abstract: To study CCDC103 expression profiles and understand how pathogenic variants in CCDC103 affect its expression profile at mRNA and protein level.
dc:source.dc:creator: Pereira R
dc:source.dc:title: Characterization of CCDC103 expression profiles: further insights in primary ciliary dyskinesia and in human reproduction.

evidence.rdfs:label: Pereira_patient2

evidence.dc:description: Patient and control cDNA, from WBC and nasal cells, was used to analyze CCDC103 mRNA expression. In WBC of the patient, mRNA expression was significantly reduced (p < 0.0001) of about 0.2-fold (Fig. 3) to controls. In nasal cells of the  patient, mRNA expression was significantly reduced (p = 0.0013) of about 0.5-fold (Fig. 3) to controls.

The frameshift variant was found in a patient with situs-inversus-totalis and primary ciliary dyskinesia, whose axoneme lack dynein arms and nexin links in the axonemes. The gene and protein expression are reduced.

evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
recurrent middle ear
disease, persistent nasal discharge, severe outer dynein arm defects observed by EM, complete cilia paralysis by HSVM

dc:source.dc:abstract: Cilia are essential for fertilization, respiratory clearance, cerebrospinal fluid circulation and establishing laterality. Cilia motility defects cause primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD, MIM244400), a disorder affecting 1:15,000-30,000 births. Cilia motility requires the assembly of multisubunit dynein arms that drive ciliary bending. Despite progress in understanding the genetic basis of PCD, mutations remain to be identified for several PCD-linked loci. Here we show that the zebrafish cilia paralysis mutant schmalhans (smh(tn222)) encodes the coiled-coil domain containing 103 protein (Ccdc103), a foxj1a-regulated gene product. Screening 146 unrelated PCD families identified individuals in six families with reduced outer dynein arms who carried mutations in CCDC103. Dynein arm assembly in smh mutant zebrafish was rescued by wild-type but not mutant human CCDC103. Chlamydomonas Ccdc103/Pr46b functions as a tightly bound, axoneme-associated protein. These results identify Ccdc103 as a dynein arm attachment factor that causes primary ciliary dyskinesia when mutated.
dc:source.dc:creator: Panizzi JR
dc:source.dc:title: CCDC103 mutations cause primary ciliary dyskinesia by disrupting assembly of ciliary dynein arms.

evidence.rdfs:label: OP-1192 II1

evidence.dc:description: Dynein arm assembly in smh mutant zebrafish was rescued by wild-type but not the mutant human CCDC103.

The variant is a homozygous 1-bp insertion (383insG) in the CCDC103 gene, resulting in a frameshift and premature termination (Gly128fsTer25). Functional studies confirmed variant pathogenecity. The mutant mRNA in smh zebrafish did not fully rescue the phenotype. The variant is reported in 6 affected members of 3 unrelated consanguineous Pakistani families. All patients showed classical PCD phenotype.

expression of CCDC103 p.His154Pro partially rescued the Zebrafish smh body axis curvature; 13 of 27 Hs-His154Pro mRNA-injected, homozygous mutants by genotype displayed a mild “bent” phenotype and lacked full curvature (Figure 3B, Supplementary Table 6), indicating that the Hs-His154Pro variant may represent a hypomorphic mutation.

This sequence change replaces histidine, which is basic and polar, with proline, which is neutral and non-polar, at codon 154 of the CCDC103 protein (p.His154Pro). Exchange of His154 for Pro results in formation of a cavity in the mutant protein and leads to exposure of a basic patch missing from the wild type protein surface. As this H154P mutant HsCCDC103 can dimerize but exhibits defective oligomerization (Shoemark et al., 2018), this structural change in the RPAP3_C domain can be directly responsible for the alterations in bulk biochemical properties (PMID: 31858719)

This variant has been observed in individuals with primary ciliary dyskinesia (PMID: 22581229, 24357714, 26123568, 28790179). Highest gnomAD MAF is 0.003234 in South Asian. Therefore, despite the functional data that demonstrated variant pathogenicity, we underscored the missence variant to .75.

The affected child carried a heterozygous transversion (c.G31C) predicting an alanine to proline change (p.Ala11Pro) with no mutation on the other allele. Because we score variants in patients carrying autosomal recessive condition (PCD, 17, autosomal recessive) we can't give this variant a score over zero.

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: patient with total sperm immotility, absence of DA and situs inversus totalis.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Perform the genetic characterization of five patients with total sperm immotility using Sanger sequencing and Whole Exome Sequencing (WES), in order to increase the knowledge on the genetics of sperm immotility and, ultimately, allow the identification of potential genetic markers for infertility.
dc:source.dc:creator: Pereira R
dc:source.dc:title: Mutation analysis in patients with total sperm immotility.

evidence.rdfs:label: Pereira R_patient 5

evidence.dc:description: The homozygous variant c.104G > C located in exon 2 of the CCDC103 gene (NM_001258398.1; 17q21.31) leads to a substitution of a conserved amino-acid arginine (R) by a proline (P) at position 35 . Three different bioinformatic tools suggested that this variant is potentially pathogenic, with the scores of 0 in SIFT, and 0.99 in Polyphen-2 and MutationTaster. Patient was detected with total sperm immotility, absence of DA and situs inversus totalis.

Western blot analysis revealed the presence of the protein in ejaculated sperm, testicular cells, cSC, with different size bands. 

IHC detection in paraffin sections of seminiferous tubules was performed. Tubulin staining was observed in the cytoplasm and perinuclear region of cells, being intense in spermatogonia (SG), moderate intense in ST1, weakly intense in ST2, Sa, and Sertoli cells, and intense in the sperm flagellum (Fig. ​(Fig.10).10). CCDC103 staining was also observed in the cytoplasm and perinuclear region of cells but, in contrast to tubulin, staining was weak in SG, intense in ST1 and ST2, moderate in Sa and Sertoli cells, and intense in the sperm midpiece
evidence.rdfs:label: Western blot and IHC analysis of CCDC103 expression

evidence.dc:description: Both Western blot and IHC analysis could detect CCDC103 protein expression. In contrast to cilia cells, the experiment demonsrated  that sperm presented the highest expression levels, 10-fold more than oocytes and about 2-fold more than WBC, which further confirms that CCDC103 may have a special role in reproductive function and corroborates findings in reproductive cells of the patients reported.
Protein expression was evaluated by ICC in nasal cells of  controls. In controls, staining was localized in the cytoplasm and at the base of cilia.
evidence.rdfs:label: Characterization of CCDC103 expression profiles

evidence.dc:description: Immunofluorescence analyses of human respiratory epithelial cells using specific antibodies directed against the outer dynein arm heavy chains DNAH5 and DNAH9  as well as the outer dynein arm intermediate chain DNAI2. As control, axoneme specific antibodies against acetylated α-tubulin  or α/β-tubulin  were used. Nuclei were stained with Hoechst 33342 . In respiratory epithelial cells from healthy probands, DNAH5  localizes along the entire length of the axonemes. In respiratory epithelial cells from patient OP-1192 carrying the CCDC103 loss-of-function mutation, DNAH5 localization is restricted to the proximal part of the axoneme and shows mis-localization to subapical cytoplasm and the perinuclear region. DNAI2 is localized along the entire length of the axonemes of healthy probands. In contrast in respiratory cells of patient OP-1192 DNAI2  localizes solely to the proximal ciliary axonemes denotes cilia tips devoid of DNAI2 .  DNAH9  localization is restricted to distal ciliary axonemes of respiratory epithelial cells from healthy probands, because it is only present in type2 ODA complexes. In the patient OP-1192 DNAH9 is completely missing  , consistent with altered assembly of type-2 ODA complexes.
evidence.rdfs:label: Mislocalization of DNAH5, DNAI2 and DNAH9 in CCDC103 mutant

evidence.dc:description: The experiment confirms the role of CCDC103 as a dynein arm assembly factor. Altered assembly of type-2 ODA complexes was evident using Immunofluorescence analyses of the CCDC103 mutant human respiratory epithelial cells.

The experiment revealed function of Ccdc103 in dynein arm assembly.

The experiment examined the Chlamydomonas ccdc103 ortholog. Ccdc103, Pr46b protein was present in both flagella and cytoplasmic extracts and migrated as apparent monomers and dimers on SDS gels (figure 5B,C), similar to protein expressed in zebrafish embryos (figure 3G). In isolated flagella, Ccdc103/Pr46b was tightly associated with axonemes even after 0.6 M NaCl extraction (figure 5B). Fractionation of Chlamydomonas cytoplasm (Figure 5C) identified Ccdc103/Pr46b in high molecular weight complexes (440 KD - 2 MD) that co-purified with outer arm dynein light chain LC2, as well as in lower molecular weight complexes (<440,000 Da). Analysis of human CCDC103 expression in respiratory epithelial cells confirmed that CCDC103 is present as apparent monomers and dimers.
evidence.rdfs:label: Ccdc103 homodimers assemble with dynein light chain 2

evidence.dc:description: Transmission electron microscopy of respiratory cilia was performed, showing normal outer- and inner-dynein arms in epithelial cells from a healthy proband. Respiratory cilia of two affected siblings carrying both identical homozygous CCDC103 loss-of-function mutations display variable defects of outer dynein arms. Cilia from patient UCL-120II2 display severe defects of the outer- and inner-dynein arms, whereas in cilia from the other affected sibling (UCL-120II3) seems to have remnant outer dynein arms.
evidence.rdfs:label: TEM of CCDC103 mutant respiratory cilia

evidence.dc:description: The effects of CCDC103 mutations were analysed by high-speed videomicroscopy of respiratory cells obtained by nasal brushing biopsy. Normal respiratory cell cilia beat vigorously and coordinately . Consistent with severe outer dynein arm defects observed by EM , patients carrying the homozygous p.Gly128fs25* mutation (OP-1193 II1) exhibited complete cilia paralysis . Patients carrying the homozygous p.His154Pro mutation exhibited either reduced cilia beat amplitude (patient OP-32II1;) or loss of beat coordination and cilia paralysis (patient OP-32II2; ), consistent with the variable reduction in EM ODA arm structure in these patients which ranged from apparently normal to complete ODA/IDA loss (patient UCL-143II1;).
evidence.rdfs:label: HSVM of CCDC103 mutant cells

evidence.dc:description: Embryo injection of myc-tagged wild-type ccdc103 mRNA rescued axis curvature, left-right asymmetry defects, and kidney cyst phenotypes, and also restored cilia motility in smh mutants , confirming that ccdc103 was the schmalhans mutant gene. Mutant Ccdc103 mRNA carrying the Q27Stop smh mutation not only failed to rescue but also increased the frequency of axis curvature defects. Antisense morpholino knockdown of ccdc103 induced curved body axes, left-right asymmetry defects, hydrocephalus, and kidney cysts , and caused cilia paralysis.
evidence.rdfs:label: Rescuing cilia paralysis in schmalhans mutants

dc:description:
*CCDC103 *mutations were first reported in 2012, in patients with dynein arm loss and a typical PCD clinical phenotype (PMID: 22581229). CCDC103 is an oligomeric outer dynein arm assembly factor that is tightly integrated within the ciliary axoneme (PMID: 25572396). Also, CCDC103 binds purified microtubules and, thus, participates in microtubule stabilization that facilitates dynein arm attachment and ciliary motility (PMID: 25572396).

Five (missense and frameshift) variants that have been reported in four publications (PMIDs: 22581229, 25877373, 31273583 and 28790179) are included in this curation. The mechanism of pathogenicity appears to be biallelic loss of function. The variant c.31G>C (p.Ala11Pro) was detected in heterozygous state in one proband (PMID: 22581229). Therefore, we didn't give it any points for this gene-disease relationship. The CCDC103 p.His154Pro substitution is relatively common in the South Asian community and causes PCD that can be difficult to diagnose using pathology-based clinical tests (PMID: 28790179). ​​The disease consistently segregates in three consanguineous Pakistani families from a UK-based genetic isolate, providing two additional points for the genetic evidence.

Experimental evidence also supports this gene-disease relationship. Immunofluorescence analyses of CCDC103 mutant human respiratory epithelial cells could detect mislocalization of the outer dynein arm heavy chains DNAH5 and DNAH9 as well as the outer dynein arm intermediate chain DNAI2. Instead of their localization along the entire length of the ciliary axonemes of healthy controls, DNAH5 and DNAI2 appeared restricted to the proximal part of the axoneme. Moreover, DNAH5 showed mis-localization to subapical cytoplasm and the perinuclear region. In a proband carrying *CCDC103* loss of function mutations, DNAH9 was completely missing, consistent with altered assembly of type-2 ODA complexes (PMID: 22581229). The mutant cells exhibit variable reduction in EM ODA arm structure ranging from apparently normal to complete ODA/IDA loss. Consistently, high speed video microscopic analysis showed variable degrees of ciliary paralysis, reduced ciliary beat amplitude, or loss of beat coordination. Western blot analysis revealed high expression levels of CCDC103 in sperm cells (PMID: 31273583). The ultrastructure of testicular sperms of an infertile patient carrying *CCDC103* biallelic mutations showed the absence of DA and DRC (PMID: 25601002). Fractionation of Chlamydomonas flagella demonstrates that Ccdc103/Pr46b is present in the flagella and remains tightly associated with NaCl extracted axonemes (PMID: 22581229). In Zebrafish schmalhans (smhtn222) mutants, injection of wild-type ccdc103 mRNA could rescue axis curvature, left-right asymmetry defects, and kidney cyst phenotypes, and also restored cilia motility. Mutant Ccdc103 mRNA not only failed to rescue but also increased the frequency of axis curvature defects (PMID: 22581229).

In summary, *CCDC103* is definitively associated with autosomal recessive Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia 17. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both research and diagnostic settings and has been upheld overtime. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Motile Ciliopathy GCEP on December 8, 2022 (SOP Version 9).
